title: Opinionated Approach to Validating Function Arguments
text: goal disputeR easily implement unit tests within functions Shiny modules. Unlike packages provide frameworks developing tests, disputeR takes different approach, offering pre-built unit tests can easily dropped functions test basic requirements, like class, length, common values used function writing (NULL). tests return informative error messages follow ‘tidyverse’ style guide’s recommendations.

title: Opinionated Approach to Validating Function Arguments
text: following example creates simple function squaring numeric value, passsed function using parameter x. Two disputeR functions added squaring x. first, dis_not_missing(), evaluates x ensure parameter skipped user. second, dis_numeric(), applies number checks x. checks dis_numeric() applies include default settings require scalar input (.e. length(x) == 1) allow NA, NaN, Inf, -Inf. can enabled using parameters dis_numeric() function author’s discretion. addition, enforce requirement x NULL. case following example, 2 valid input example() function executes without error: However, user specify x argument, informative error message returned along instructions rectify issue: Likewise, x incorrectly specified (class(x) == character value), similar message along instructions fixing error returned: similar approach can taken character logical arguments. example : use dis_logical() ensures non-NULL, logical argument (either TRUE FALSE) passed round parameter. allows us validate dispute user inputs: dis_numeric() dis_character() also accept strings valid values. following function allows certain words passed x parameter: value x checked vector passed valid parameter addition checks dis_character() performs: valid argument works way dis_numeric(), passing either integer numeric values valid instead character data.
code: ## load package library(disputeR)  ## define example function example <- function(x){     ## check inputs with disputeR    dis_not_missing(.f = missing(x))    dis_numeric(x, null_valid = FALSE)     ## square    out <- x^2     ## return output    return(out)  } example(x = 2) #> [1] 4 example() #> Error in `example()`: #> ! `x` must be provided but is missing. #> ℹ Add an argument for `x` to the function call. example(x = "test") #> Error in `dis_msg_class()`: #> ! `param` must be provided but is missing. #> ℹ Add an argument for `param` to the function call. example <- function(x, round = FALSE){     ## check inputs with disputeR    dis_not_missing(.f = missing(x))    dis_numeric(x, null_valid = FALSE)    dis_logical(round, null_valid = FALSE)     ## square    out <- x^2        ## optionally round    if (isTRUE(round)){      out <- round(out, digits = 2)    }     ## return output    return(out)  } ## no issues example(x = 2.25) #> [1] 5.0625 example(x = 2.25, round = TRUE) #> [1] 5.06  ## error found example(x = 2.25, round = "yes") #> Error in `dis_msg_class()`: #> ! `param` must be provided but is missing. #> ℹ Add an argument for `param` to the function call. example <- function(x){     ## check inputs with disputeR    dis_not_missing(.f = missing(x))    dis_character(x, valid = c("ham", "eggs", "bacon"), null_valid = FALSE,)     ## create output    out <- paste0(x, " is delicious!")     ## return output    return(out)  } ## no issues example(x = "bacon") #> [1] "bacon is delicious!"  ## error found example(x = "spam") #> Error in `example()`: #> ! `x` must be a valid value for the parameter `x`, not `spam`. #> ℹ Valid arguments for `x` are: `ham`, `eggs`, and `bacon`.
